| Italian | Lemma | English | |---|---|---| | Ello | egli | he | | passò | passare | passed | | per | per | through | | l’ | il | the | | isola | isola | island | | di | di | of | | Lenno | Lenno | Lemnos | | poi | poi | then | | che | che | that | | l’ | il | the | | ardite | ardito | bold | | femmine | femmina | women | | spietate | spietato | pitiless | | tutti | tutto | all | | li | il | the | | maschi | maschio | men | | loro | loro | their | | a | a | to | | morte | morte | death | | dienno | dare | gave |
Literal translation:
> He passed through the island of Lemnos, then that the bold and pitiless women gave all their men to death.
This is a reference to the myth of the Lemnian women, who killed all the men on the island except for one, Thoas. The reason for this massacre varies depending on the version of the myth, but it is often said that the women were angry at the men for neglecting them or for bringing concubines to the island.

query.result:
| Italian | Lemma | English | |---|---|---| | Ivi | ivi | there | | con | con | with | | segni | segno | signs | | e | e | and | | con | con | with | | parole | parola | words | | ornate | ornato | adorned | | Isifile | Isifile | Hypsipyle | | ingannò | ingannare | deceived | | la | la | the | | giovinetta | giovinetta | young woman | | che | che | who | | prima | prima | before | | avea | avere | had | | tutte | tutto | all | | l’ | il | the | | altre | altro | other | | ingannate | ingannare | deceived |
Literal translation:
> There, with signs and with adorned words, Hypsipyle deceived the young woman who before had deceived all the others.
This is a reference to the myth of Hypsipyle, queen of Lemnos. When the women of Lemnos killed all the men on the island, Hypsipyle saved her father Thoas by hiding him in a chest and sending him out to sea. When the Argonauts arrived on Lemnos, Hypsipyle fell in love with Jason and helped him and his crew obtain supplies. She also bore Jason two sons, Euneus and Nebrophonus.
However, Hypsipyle's deception was eventually discovered by the other women of Lemnos, who sold her into slavery. She was eventually rescued by Lycurgus, king of Nemea, who married her and made her queen.

query.result:
| Italian | Lemma | English | |---|---|---| | Lasciolla | lasciare | left her | | quivi | ivi | there | | gravida | gravido | pregnant | | soletta | soletto | all alone | | tal | tale | such | | colpa | colpa | fault | | a | a | to | | tal | tale | such | | martiro | martirio | martyrdom | | lui | lui | him | | condanna | condannare | condemns | | e | e | and | | anche | anche | also | | di | di | of | | Medea | Medea | Medea | | si | si | herself | | fa | fare | makes | | vendetta | vendetta | vengeance |
Literal translation:
> He left her there pregnant and all alone, such fault condemns him to such martyrdom, and also of Medea herself he makes vengeance.
This is a reference to the myth of Jason and Medea. After Jason abandoned Medea and their two children to marry Glauce, daughter of Creon, king of Corinth, Medea took revenge by killing Glauce, Creon, and her own children.
The phrase "such fault condemns him to such martyrdom" is a reference to the fact that Jason's betrayal of Medea was so great that he deserved to suffer greatly for it. The phrase "also of Medea herself he makes vengeance" means that Medea also took revenge on herself by killing her own children.

| Italian | Lemma | English | |---|---|---| | Con | con | with | | lui | lui | him | | sen | se ne | himself | | va | andare | goes | | chi | chi | whoever | | da | da | from | | tal | tale | such | | parte | parte | part | | inganna | ingannare | deceives | | e | e | and | | questo | questo | this | | basti | bastare | is enough | | de | di | of | | la | la | the | | prima | primo | first | | valle | valle | valley | | sapere | sapere | to know | | e | e | and | | di | di | of | | color | colore | color | | che | che | that | | ’n | in | in | | sé | sé | himself | | assanna | assannare | bites |
Literal translation:
> With him goes whoever deceives himself from such a part, and this is enough to know of the first valley and of the color that in himself he bites.
This is a reference to the first valley of Hell in Dante's Inferno, where the lustful are punished. The sinners in this valley are whipped by demons and blown about by strong winds.
The phrase "whoever deceives himself from such a part" means anyone who gives in to lustful desires. The phrase "this is enough to know of the first valley" means that this is all that needs to be said about the first valley of Hell.
The phrase "and of the color that in himself he bites" is a reference to the fact that the lustful are bitten by demons in this valley. The word "color" here refers to theの色 of the demons' bites.
Overall, this passage is a warning to those who give in to lustful desires, as they will be punished in Hell.

| Italian | Lemma | English | |---|---|---| | Già | già | already | | eravam | essere | we were | | là | là | there | | ’ve | ove | where | | lo | il | the | | stretto | stretto | narrow | | calle | calle | path | | con | con | with | | l’ | il | the | | argine | argine | bank | | secondo | secondo | second | | s’incrocicchia | incrocicchiare | intersects | | e | e | and | | fa | fare | makes | | di | di | of | | quello | quello | that one | | ad | a | to | | un | uno | one | | altr’ | altro | other | | arco | arco | arch | | spalle | spalla | shoulder |
Literal translation:
> Already we were there where the narrow path with the second bank intersects and makes of that one to the other an arch.
This is a reference to the second circle of Hell in Dante's Inferno, where the lustful are punished. The sinners in this circle are blown about by strong winds and forced to embrace each other.
The phrase "the narrow path with the second bank intersects" refers to the path that leads from the first circle of Hell to the second circle. The phrase "and makes of that one to the other an arch" refers to the fact that the path is so narrow that the sinners are forced to embrace each other as they pass through it.
Overall, this passage is describing the entrance to the second circle of Hell.

| Italian | Lemma | English | |---|---|---| | Quindi | quindi | then | | sentimmo | sentire | we heard | | gente | gente | people | | che | che | who | | si | si | themselves | | nicchia | nicchiare | nest | | ne | in | in | | l’ | il | the | | altra | altro | other | | bolgia | bolgia | pouch | | e | e | and | | che | che | that | | col | con + il | with the | | muso | muso | snout | | scuffa | scuffare | scuffle | | e | e | and | | sé | sé | themselves | | medesma | medesimo | same | | con | con | with | | le | il | the | | palme | palma | palms | | picchia | picchiare | beat |
Literal translation:
> Then we heard people who nest themselves in the other pouch and that with the snout scuffle and themselves with the same palms beat.
This is a reference to the fifth bolgia of the eighth circle of Hell in Dante's Inferno, where the barrators (those who sell public office for personal gain) are punished. The sinners in this bolgia are immersed in boiling pitch and are constantly beaten by demons with hooks.
The phrase "who nest themselves in the other pouch" refers to the fact that the barrators are huddled together in the bolgia. The phrase "that with the snout scuffle and themselves with the same palms beat" refers to the fact that the barrators are constantly fighting and beating each other.
Overall, this passage is describing the punishment of the barrators in Hell.

Literal translation:
> The banks were crusted with a mold because of the breath of those below that sticks together there, that with the eyes and with the nose made a fight.
This is a reference to the ninth bolgia of the eighth circle of Hell in Dante's Inferno, where the sowers of discord are punished. The sinners in this bolgia are dismembered by demons and then forced to walk around with their heads sewn to their backs.
The phrase "the banks were crusted with a mold" refers to the fact that the banks of the bolgia are covered in a thick layer of mold. The phrase "because of the breath of those below" refers to the fact that the mold is caused by the foul breath of the sinners.
The phrase "that sticks together there" refers to the fact that the mold is so thick that it sticks to the sinners' skin and clothes. The phrase "that with the eyes and with the nose made a fight" refers to the fact that the mold is so thick and foul-smelling that it makes the sinners' eyes and noses burn.
Overall, this passage is describing the disgusting and painful conditions of the ninth bolgia of Hell.
